title: Irish question may drive a stake through Boris' Halloween Brexit
text:
MPs have passed a law, now known as "the Benn Act", preventing Mr Johnson from leaving the EU without a deal on October 31. Mr Johnson's aide said if the Prime Minister were legally forced to seek a delay, voters would know who to blame - and it wasn't the Conservatives.

Labour's shadow Brexit secretary, Keir Starmer, hit back against the briefings: “It’s parliament’s fault, it’s the opposition’s fault, it’s the Benn Act, it’s Germany, it’s Ireland - absolutely defining the character of this prime minister, a man who never takes responsibility for his own actions,” he told MPs.

Playing the blame game ... British Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Bloomberg

The Europeans were equally caustic. “Boris Johnson, what’s at stake is not winning some stupid blame game. At stake is the future of Europe and the UK as well as the security and interests of our people,” tweeted European Council President Donald Tusk.

Brexiteers, meanwhile, immediately piled in on the other side. The Twitter account of Leave.EU, funded by multimillionaire and Nigel Farage associate Arron Banks, didn't hold back: "We didn't win two world wars to be pushed around by a Kraut!".

The last scrap of hope for a deal lies with Ireland, where Prime Minister Leo Varadkar's government is calling the EU's negotiating tune.

Eyes on the Irish

Advertisement

If they're prepared to compromise and accept elements of Mr Johnson's plan for two separate borders around Northern Ireland - one with Britain for customs, one with the EU for regulations - the Europeans would go along with it. Whether it can be made legally watertight by an EU summit on October 17-18 is another question.

On Wednesday morning (AEDT) the Irish were sounding emollient - though it was unclear whether this was genuine, or at attempt to side-step the attribution of fault.

"Certainly there are some in the UK who seem to be planning for a general election ahead of trying to plan to get a deal," said Ireland's deputy prime minister, Simon Coveney.

"Our focus not to get distracted with the blame game, because ultimately this is about finding a way of getting a deal."

Mr Coveney said Ireland's focus was on "trying to close a gap between two negotiating teams ... that will allow the EU to support a way forward, and a way forward the UK can accept as well but that finds a way of avoiding the need to put border infrastructure near the border on the island of Ireland".

"We know the impact that would have on politics on the island of Ireland, north and south, not just the impact on trade, and that’s why we are so determined to avoid it.

"The focus has to be back where it needs to be, which is here in Brussels between two negotiating teams."

Advertisement

Domestic disquiet

Some moderate Conservative cabinet ministers are said to be alarmed about the tough rhetoric coming from Mr Johnson's aides. Commentators are speculating that several ministers may yet resign, but Mr Johnson seems determined to crash through or crash out.

Meanwhile, the government again prorogued parliament on Tuesday night (Wednesday AEDT), this time for five days - a more typical prorogation that is unlikely to attract controversy.

That paves the way for a Queen's speech on October 14, when the monarch attends Parliament and reads out the government's new legislative program.

Mr Johnson will use the speech to reiterate his non-Brexit battle lines for the election, which is expected before the year's end: a program of public largesse on police, hospitals and schools designed to win over socially conservative blue-collar voters.

The government also pressed on with no-deal Brexit preparations, releasing a "Brexit readiness report" that updated the tariff schedules and administrative requirements to be used if Britain crashes out on October 31.

One cross-bench peer, the barrister David Anderson, noted that if Brexit was a project to slough off unwanted regulation, right now it was having the opposite effect, at least for those with any traffic with the EU.

"Today’s 'no-deal readiness report' illustrates on page after page how our hard-won freedoms and those of other Europeans are to be throttled by new red tape, 28 years after Thatcher’s European Commissioner, Arthur Cockfield, achieved the Single Market on 1 Jan 1993 with the biggest bonfire of red tape in modern history," he said on Twitter.
description: The UK government downplays hopes of striking a Brexit deal, seemingly accepting a delay to Prime Minister Boris Johnson's October 31 deadline is inevitable.
